column4: can someone tell me how to set the PATH? sipior told me something like "export PATH=$:/directory"; Is this correct?
i mean "export PATH=$PATH:/directory"
from the command line already i assume?
yes
then yes, that will do it for one session. do you want it for just one session, or for forever?
oh, i need to permanently change it
i see. hold on a sec ...
ok, open your ~/.bashrc and add at the end the 'export PATH="$PATH:/path/to/directory"'
what is ~/.bashrc and where is it?
~/ is a shortcut to your home directory, so ~/.bashrc is a text file in your home directory that starts with a . aka it's hidden.
i get permission denied when i type ~/.bashrc
ok. just run this command and the text editor will open: 'gedit ~/.bashrc'
so i just add the export to the end? I have another location that i must also add to the PATH so would I write another "export" line?
yep, at the end. no, you'd put both in the same line: "export PATH=$PATH:/path/to/directory1:/directory2/path/here"
is there a space between the  1st and 2nd directories?
no. a space will break it.
in fact, if you have spaces in any of the names of the directorys, the export line has to be slightly different.
i think i have to reboot for the PATH changes to take place?
no. just restart bash.
how do i restart bash?
close the terminal, reopen.
